ideas:
[Evaluation] Dynamic Attention Network for Visual Scene Understanding

This research explores a novel dynamic attention mechanism for visual scene understanding, aiming to improve performance on complex scenes with occlusions and varying object scales. The idea involves extending the standard self-attention mechanism to incorporate a "contextual memory" layer that dynamically adjusts the attention weights based on recent visual input. We will evaluate the network on a dataset of human-annotated scenes with varying levels of occlusion and object scale using metrics like Mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) and a custom metric measuring the accuracy of object segmentation.

[Cognitive Science] Exploring the Role of Predictive Coding in Social Memory Consolidation

This research investigates how predictive coding mechanisms influence the consolidation of social memories – memories of interactions with others. I will build a simulated environment where participants are presented with a series of social interactions, and then receive a "prediction" of the likely outcome of the interaction.  The goal is to determine if participants exhibit increased memory consolidation when they receive a more accurate prediction, compared to a less accurate one. Data will include EEG recordings to measure neural activity associated with prediction and consolidation, and a subjective rating of memory recall accuracy. Metrics will include accuracy of recall and subjective ratings of emotional intensity.

[Safety] Bias Detection in Personalized Recommendation Systems

This research will develop a novel method for detecting subtle biases embedded within personalized recommendation systems by analyzing the diversity of items presented to users. I will build a system that identifies when a user consistently receives recommendations that are highly similar to those they’ve previously engaged with, even if those recommendations are not explicitly biased. Data will include user interaction history, item metadata, and a measure of similarity between items. Evaluation will involve comparing the system’s detection rate to human annotators and assessing the impact on user satisfaction.

[ML] Personalized Synthetic Data Generation for Climate Modeling

This project aims to develop a system that generates synthetic climate data tailored to specific model parameters and scenarios, significantly augmenting existing datasets for improved climate modeling accuracy. The system will utilize a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) trained on a large collection of historical climate data, with the generator producing synthetic data that closely mimics the statistical properties of the real data. Evaluation will be based on comparing the synthetic data to real data using metrics like statistical similarity (e.g., Kolmogorov-Smirnov test) and model performance on a climate model validation set.

[HCI] Personalized Embodied Feedback for Navigation Assistance

This research explores the integration of haptic feedback into a mobile navigation app to provide personalized, contextual guidance. Users will wear a small, lightweight device that delivers subtle vibrations and tactile cues based on their current location and planned route. The system will learn user preferences through a short onboarding phase and adapt feedback based on observed behavior (e.g., avoiding obstacles, quickly finding routes). Evaluation will involve measuring task completion time, user satisfaction (using a Likert scale), and the frequency of successful navigation.

[NLP] Personalized Dialogue Style Analysis using Transformer Networks

This research explores the impact of dialogue style on user engagement and satisfaction in virtual assistants. I will develop a transformer-based model that analyzes user responses to virtual assistants, identifying distinct stylistic patterns (e.g., formal, informal, humorous) and correlating these patterns with user sentiment and task completion rates. Data will include a dataset of user-assistant interactions, labeled with stylistic features and user feedback. Evaluation will be based on user satisfaction scores and task completion time.

[NLP] Discourse-Aware Sentiment Prediction with Knowledge Graph Integration
This research investigates the integration of knowledge graphs into sentiment prediction models, aiming to improve accuracy by leveraging contextual knowledge and relationships between entities. The model will be trained on a dataset of social media posts, incorporating external knowledge from a curated knowledge graph (e.g., Wikidata) to enhance sentiment understanding. Evaluation will be based on F1-score and a novel metric assessing the coherence and consistency of the model’s sentiment predictions with the knowledge graph.

[Vision] Visual Grounding for Dialogue Response Generation

This research investigates the integration of visual cues (e.g., facial expressions, body posture) with textual dialogue to improve the coherence and naturalness of response generation. We will develop a model that learns to associate visual features with specific dialogue intents, enabling the system to better understand the user’s emotional state and intentions, leading to more engaging and relevant responses. Evaluation will be conducted using a dataset of multi-modal dialogues, focusing on metrics like user engagement and task completion rate.
[NLP] Contextual Sentiment Analysis of Social Media Posts for Proactive Crisis Detection

[NLP] Contextualized Sentiment Analysis with Implicit Belief Modeling

This research investigates a method for improving sentiment analysis by incorporating implicit beliefs about the topic being discussed. It will develop a model that learns to predict the user's underlying beliefs about a given text, rather than solely relying on explicit sentiment labels. The model will utilize a transformer architecture and incorporate a knowledge graph to represent and reason about the topic's context. Evaluation will be based on a held-out dataset of text with known implicit beliefs and a separate test set measuring the accuracy of predicting these beliefs.

[NLP] Text-to-Image Generation with Emotional Contextualization

This research explores the integration of emotional sentiment analysis into text-to-image generation models to create images that better reflect the intended emotional state of the user. We will train a diffusion model to generate images from text prompts, but incorporate a separate model that analyzes the text prompt for emotional cues (e.g., using sentiment analysis from a pre-trained model) and then injects this emotional context into the image generation process. The goal is to improve user satisfaction and potentially enable more nuanced and expressive image generation.

[NLP] Contextualized Sentiment Analysis of Social Media Posts

This research explores the development of a novel contextualized sentiment analysis model that goes beyond simple polarity detection by incorporating discourse-level cues and emotional tone. The model will be trained on a large dataset of social media posts, utilizing a transformer architecture augmented with a discourse parsing module to identify key phrases and relationships between sentences. Evaluation will be based on a held-out test set measuring accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, comparing against a baseline model trained on standard sentiment analysis techniques.

[Evaluation] Dynamic Attention Mechanism for Visual Question Answering

This research explores a novel dynamic attention mechanism for visual question answering (VQA) that adapts attention weights based on the temporal coherence of the visual input and the question. Current VQA models often struggle with long-range dependencies and inconsistent reasoning. We will develop a mechanism that learns to prioritize relevant visual features and question components, improving accuracy and robustness. Data will be a dataset of images paired with questions and answers, and evaluation will be based on accuracy on a held-out test set and a user study measuring coherence of answers. Metrics will include Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR) and human evaluation of answer quality.

[HCI] Personalized Embodied Feedback for Navigation Assistance

This research explores the integration of haptic feedback into a mobile navigation app to provide users with more intuitive and personalized guidance. We will develop a system that uses subtle vibrations to indicate the direction of movement and potential obstacles, tailored to the user’s gait and preferred navigation style. The system will be evaluated through user studies measuring task completion time, error rates, and subjective ratings of comfort and ease of use. Metrics will include frequency of successful navigation and user reported feelings of confidence.

[NLP] Contextualized Semantic Embedding for Dialogue Generation

This research proposes a novel contextualized semantic embedding approach for dialogue generation, leveraging a transformer-based model trained on a large corpus of multi-turn conversations. Current dialogue systems often produce generic responses, failing to maintain consistent context and exhibit limited understanding of user intent. We will develop a model that learns to generate responses that are not only grammatically correct but also reflect the evolving conversational history, using a contrastive learning objective to encourage similarity between generated responses and the context. Evaluation will be based on user satisfaction ratings and task completion rates.

[NLP] Visual-Textual Sentiment Alignment for Crisis Prediction

This research will develop a system that aligns visual and textual sentiment expressed in social media posts with a specific crisis event, using a transformer model to identify correlations between image and text cues. The system will leverage a dataset of social media posts and corresponding images, and evaluate performance using a custom metric combining precision and recall on crisis prediction tasks.

[NLP] Contextualized Sentiment Analysis of Social Media Posts for Proactive Crisis Detection

This research will develop a novel system for identifying potential social media crises by analyzing the sentiment expressed within posts related to a specific event or topic. The system will utilize a transformer-based model fine-tuned on a labeled dataset of social media posts, incorporating a novel attention mechanism to focus on the most emotionally charged words and phrases. Evaluation will be based on precision and recall for detecting emerging crisis indicators, as well as a user-defined metric of time to detection.

[Safety] Algorithmic Bias Detection in Autonomous Vehicle Perception Systems

This research will develop a novel framework for detecting and quantifying algorithmic bias in pedestrian detection models used by autonomous vehicles. The framework will leverage a combination of adversarial training and explainable AI (XAI) techniques to identify disparities in detection rates across demographic groups (e.g., based on age, race, and gender). We will evaluate the framework using a publicly available dataset of pedestrian images and metrics such as precision, recall, and F1-score, focusing on identifying patterns indicative of biased model behavior.
